description: From Middle English abaishment, from Middle French abaissement (“astonishment”) alteration of esbaissement, from esbaiss + -ment. Compare French ébahissement. Equivalent to abash +‎ -ment.

entries.meaning: The state of being abashed; embarrassment from shame. [First attested from 1350 to 1470.]
examples: And the lorde shall smyte the with madnesse, and blyndnesse & abashment of herte.
